document.masterDocTitle: The genus Trichoscypha (Anacardiaceae) in Lower Guinea and Congolia: A synoptic revision

mods:titleInfo.mods:title: The genus Trichoscypha (Anacardiaceae) in Lower Guinea and Congolia: A synoptic revision

caption.paragraph:
FIG. 8. — Distribution of
Trichoscypha lucens Oliv.

subSubSection.paragraph: Trees, or more rarely, scandent shrub or liana. Leaves (4-)5-10(-13)-jugate; leaflets papery to coriaceous, the lowest pair sometimes close to the stem, (2-)10-25(-36) × (1-)4-7(-12) cm, with 10- 16 pairs of main lateral nerves, ± glabrous above except for the usually pubescent, impressed midrib, ± glabrous to sparsely appressed-puberulous to pubescent beneath, usually minutely pustulate above. Inflorescence brown-velutinous, (sub)terminal or borne below the leaves. Flowers (Jan.-Dec.) with white to pinkish petals. Fruits (June-Feb.) pink to dark red, subellipsoid, up to 3 × 2 cm , densely to sparsely hairy. — Figs 1I ; 8.

HABITAT AND DISTRIBUTION. — Rain forest of Lower Guinea and Congolia extending to the areas of the Flora of Tropical East Africa and Flora Zambesiaca. Alt. up to c. 2000 m . Also known from Upper Guinea .
SELECTED SPECIMENS. — ANGOLA : Gossweiler
11423 , Dala, fl. Apr. (BM!, BR!, COI!). — BENIN :

NOTES . — In Upper Guinea
Trichoscypha lucens
has always been reported as a shrub or small tree, the lectotype from outside this area, collected by
Mann
, being the only exception ( BRETELER 2001: 261 ). Although the material from Lower Guinea
and Congolia has a similar habit, a few collectors have described plants as lianas or lianescent shrubs, e.g., Leeuwenberg 5335 from Cameroun , Devred 1980 and 2076 from Congo (Kinshasa), and Lewalle 6124 from Burundi .

The neotypes chosen for three synonyms,
T.coriacea
,
T. ledermannii
, and
T. pallidiflora
, have, as far as possible, been selected according to the origin of the type material (which appears to have been lost at Berlin) and the original description.

Of the 12 new species described for the
Flore du Congo Belge et du Ruanda-Urundi
by VAN DER VEKEN (1959 , 1966 ), seven are treated here as synonyms of
T. lucens
, one of the very variable species of
Trichoscypha
and the most wide spread. VAN DER VEKEN (1960) distinguished these seven species both by habit and leaflet characteristics, such as shape, size, texture, and details of the acumen. These elements have proven to be of little or no value for specific segregation.
